results.title: B.L.A.C.K.: an Aboriginal song of hip hop
results.creator_credit: Roslyn Baker, Grant Saunders and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
B.L.A.C.K. is a cipher scribed by independent and Indigenous Hip Hop artist, Wire MC. Through interviews and observation the song is visually and dialectically deconstructed to speak of contemporary issues around Aboriginal blackness, politics and culture.
The filmmaker, with his own roots in Hip Hop, aligns himself with Wire MC and through a rapped narrative adds another layer of complexity to notions of blackness by pulling apart his own identity.
This is a musical documentary that exposes an authentic and empowering B.L.A.C.K. voice existing underneath the hype of “bling-bling” hip hop. This is a film with rhythm, rhyme and reason.

results.title: B.B.C. television: the first 25 years
results.brief_description: Describes Britain’s pioneering efforts with this medium, showing how the demands of war accelerated technical development and how the post-war years nursed the nation-wide impact of this home entertainment. The opening of the first regular television service from Alexandra Palace, London, in 1936; highlights from popular programmes and the linking of the BBC service with Eurovision and Intervision 25 years later. A record of successful transmission from Britain to Australia indicates a path of future achievement.

results.title: Azzel
results.creator_credit: J.-P. Olivier Fougeres, Peter McCaw, Peter Hollander, Guy L. Cote and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Azzel is the name of one of the first schools for nomads opened by the Niger Department of National Education. The film describes the traditional nomadic lifestyle of the Tuareg and the changes brought about in the lives of the children attending the government-run boarding schools.

results.title: Azumi
results.creator_credit: Ryuhei Kitamura, Mataichiro Yamamoto, Toshiyaki Nakazawa, Toho Kabushiki Kaisha and Sedic International Inc
results.brief_description: Orphaned as a young girl, Azumi is brought up by a masterly warrior to be a highly skilled, trained assassin. One of a band of children brought up in this manner, as adults the crew are sent off to eliminate corrupt warlords who are preventing peace in the land. In battle Azumi and her group encounter an array of fierce and exotic enemies whilst contending with their internal conflicts. Based on the Manga comic, “Azumi” is great fun with its colourful villains and incessant action sequences; although at times quite cheesy, the over-the-top nature of the director’s aesthetic combines well with his flair for outrageous gore and mordant humour.

results.title: Azhari Ali: an Acehnese university student
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Keith Gow, John Morris and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours: Indonesia”.
Set in the city of Banda Acec, this film traces the daily life of Azhari Ali, a student of agriculture at the University of Syiah Kuala. He is a devout Moslem. His lodgings and some money were provided by the Mosque authorities. This money provides his travel to the University, some extra money is gained by teaching the Koran five nights a week. Only late at night can this ambitious 25 year-old find time to study away from his daily commitments.

results.title: Ayers Rock; Brick and Tile; Incongruous
results.brief_description: A collection of three experimental films made by filmmaker, Paul Winkler. These films present fascinating combinations, juxtapositions and manipulation of moving and still images. The first film makes use of images of the Ayers Rock, Australian bushland, and patterns from aboriginal bark paintings. The second film uses images of bricks and tiles. The last film shows juxtaposition of rural and urban images. Each film has an interesting soundtrack, matching the moving images.

results.title: Ayers Rock
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Arid Landforms”.
Gives examples of Australian landforms resulting from weathering and erosion in arid regions. Illustrates examples of weathering and erosion responsible for producing the features seen in Ayers Rock. Shows three types of residuals found in arid Central Australia, kinds of weathering responsible for the formation of Ayers Rock and emphasises geological time periods. Also notes in detail the caves, grooves and guttering, and the under-cut base caused by running water. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Aya
results.creator_credit: Solrun Hoaas, Denise Patience and Goshu Films
results.brief_description: The story of Aya, the Japanese war bride of an Australian serviceman, spans over twenty years from the early fifties to to the mid-seventies. Hoaas’ intention was to question Australian attitudes to Asians and to express, through the character of Aya’s husband Frank, some disturbing contradictions in the Australian male psyche. In her examination of cross-cultural complexities Hoaas is reticent in projecting feelings, adopting a somewhat elliptical approach to dramatising Aya’s relationship.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Solrun Hoaas, Denise Patience and Goshu Films

results.title: Ay Carmela
results.creator_credit: Carlos Saura, Andres Gomes, Television Espanola, Ellepi Films and Iberoamerican Films
results.brief_description: Ay Carmela is set during the Spanish Civil War in 1938 when control of the cities and towns was continually in a state of flux as the communist Republican armies battled with the Franco led fascist forces in attacks and counter-attacks. Carmela (Carmen Maura - “Women on the verge of a nervous breakdown” 1987) and Paulino (Andres Pajares) along with the mute Gustavete (Gabino Diego) have been travelling on the road entertaining frontline Republican troops under the banner of the Tip-Top Variety Show. Carmela sings and dances, Paulino recites poetry and Gustavete plays guitar and together they perform and act out short comedic scenes and entertain in the true vaudevillian tradition. However when they are captured by Mussolini’s soldiers on their way to Valencia, choices have to be made. Morality, loyalty, survival are put to the test for Carmela and Paulino, both on a personal and artist’s level. Will they resist, or co-operate with the demands put on them to perform for the Fascist officers and a group of captured Polish prisoners who are doomed to be executed the morning after the show? And what about the Italian Lieutenant who is in charge of producing/directing the show - can Carmela and Paulino agree to the changes in the words of their songs and poetry to reflect the fascist ideology? Will they compromise themselves to save their own lives? “Ay Carmela” is a strange blend of farcical comedy, music, dance, and politics and may prove a disappointment to Carlos Saura fans (director of Carmen and Blood Wedding). However, Carmen Maura puts in an excellent performance as does Andres Pajares and the theme of artists and morality is an interesting one. Cast also includes Maurizio de Razza, Jose Sancho, Mario de Candia, Miguel Angel Rellan, Edward Zentara. A Spanish-Italian co-production.
